DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0721 with `p' category code
1992: Nobody's Running, but Nobody's Sitting Still Either
DOC.TEXT: The name doesn't matter. Any Democratic heavyweight will do: They're all professing no interest whatsoever in taking on President Bush in 1992. ``I have no plans to run for president in 1992,'' declares Sen. Sam Nunn of Georgia. ``I'm focusing on my re-election next year,'' says Sen. Al Gore of Tennessee. ``I'm not running and I'm not making any plans to run,'' chimes in Sen. Lloyd Bentsen of Texas. Ditto for Sen. Bill Bradley of New Jersey, Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York and civil rights leader Jesse Jackson. So is it Bush and Quayle unopposed for re-election in 1992? No chance. While there is remarkably little overt activity among the potential Democratic challengers, there is always something stirring in presidential politics. Even those who deny any interest find their hearts beat a little faster when they breathe the cool, clean air of Iowa and New Hampshire. Bradley was in Des Moines over the summer to speak at a fund-raiser for Sen. Tom Harkin, D-Iowa, who faces a tough Republican challenge in 1990. While he was there, he met with Tony Bisignano, a union official and state legislator. Bisignano was impressed. He said they didn't talk about 1992, but he'd be eager to start a ``low-key, grassroots organization'' to drum up support for Bradley. Bentsen, meanwhile, was the featured speaker at the Iowa Democratic Party's Jefferson-Jackson Day dinner this fall. New Hampshire, the state which has the quadrennial distinction of holding the first presidential primary, has had visits in 1989 from Rep. Pat Schroeder of Colorado and Gov. Richard Celeste of Ohio. Both came close to entering the 1988 presidential race. Sen. Robert Kerrey of Nebraska had a long lunch in Boston this fall with a group of political operatives who have had extensive experience in Democratic presidential campaigns. ``He just wanted to know what was on people's minds,'' said Larry Rasky, a public relations executive who worked on Sen. Joe Biden's 1988 campaign. Cuomo has said an indication that he is planning a presidential bid would be an announcement that he will not run for a third term as governor of New York. He's not giving that signal, at least not now. In a telephone interview, he said he's leaning toward another gubernatorial campaign. ``There's just nothing I can do that's as important as this,'' he said. But somehow, Cuomo finds it impossible to stop thinking about running for president. An example of his ambivalence came last summer when he invited a reporter to ask him about the possibility that he might seek the presidency. ``I want to talk about it, because I want to dispose of it,'' he said, declaring that he was tired of speculation about his plans. ``And so,'' he said, ``for the time being I'm not going to discuss it.''
